references: To remedy the previous works only accepting single text instructions, in this paper, we introduce a novel system, MLLM-Tool, integrating multi-modal encoders with open-source LLMs to synthesize multi-modal information for correct external tool identification. The distinction between our work and previous works is delineated in Table               1             . Compared to previous open-sourced works, our system is the first attempt to train a large multi-modal model for tool agent learning. In light of the fact that existing tool learning benchmarks         [                  15                ,                  12                ,                  39                ,                  23                ,                  21                ,                  37                ,                  42                ,                  27                ]        , do not explicitly construct text-to-any-modality pairs for alleviating text ambiguity, which cannot facilitate the training of our MLLM-Tool, in this paper, we collect a novel dataset, named ToolMMBench from the HuggingFace platform, one of the largest machine learning communities containing thousands of APIs. It is also worth noting that our ToolMMBench supports multi-options for each query, as demonstrated in Table               1             . This feature is more closely related to real-life scenarios, where multiple alternatives exist to address the same challenges, albeit with varying performance levels. Such a feature would also make our dataset suitable for other applications in future, such as the study of integrating multiple outputs from different tools to better feedback to the user.

table: Audio Classification Audio-to-Text Audio-to-Audio Voice Activity Detection Video Classification Video-to-Text Depth Estimation Image Classification Image Segmentation Image-to-Image Visual Question Answering Image-to-Text Zero-Shot Image Classification Multimodal-to-Image Object Detection Feature Extraction Fill-Mask Text Generation Text Generation Text Classification Question Answering Sentence Similarity Summarization Text-to-Image Text-to-Speech Text-to-Video Text-to-Text Translation Zero-Shot Classification
references: It is worth noticing that the function classification rules formulated by the HuggingFace platform are coarse-grained and not suitable for direct use by our work for some reasons. In particular, some models lack assigned categories or are incorrectly classified, or they contain multiple tasks but only one of them is labeled. Additionally, the platform employs overly coarse, resulting in a loss of fine-grained distinctions. For example, the task of           Audio Classification          , can be subdivided into           Event Recognition, Command Recognition, Spoken Language Identification, Speaker Verification, etc          . We then propose a new hierarchical function categorization system and rearrange the filtered model. We list all the tasks our system supports in Table                  2                , and for the subtasks we divide under these tasks, we provide more detailed information in the Appendix.

table: Settings Text Audio Image Video Training Set (w/ split) 31,280 2,944 10,085 224 Training Set (w/o split) 5,563 562 3,938 82 Testing Set 1,452 164 760 21
references: We divide our dataset into training and testing sets in an 8:2 ratio. Since our task currently focuses on a closed set of APIs, our test set cannot include any APIs that haven‚Äôt been encountered in the training set. Therefore, we approach this from the perspective of queries generated by each API. Given the presence of one-to-many query scenarios in our dataset, we implement a strategy in the training set to address these cases. Specifically, we split each one-to-many query into           W          distinct inputs, where           W          represents the number of APIs that support the given query. This approach ensures that each potential API response is individually represented, allowing the model to learn the diverse range of suitable responses for a single query. In contrast to the training sampling strategy, for the one-to-many query scenarios in our dataset, each query appears only once in the test set. Finally, the training set comprises 44,533 instructions, containing 9,245 different instructions, and the testing set totaled 2,397 instructions. The detailed distribution is illustrated in Table                  3                .

references: Ambiguity types          . In Table                  6                , we provide the results for five types of ambiguity, and the comparison between non-ambiguity and ambiguity cases. We find that the ambiguity types I (Domains) and II (Categories) perform worst in ambiguity handling. In contrast, other categories excel, especially type V (Language) achieves 100% accuracy when trained 5 epochs for 7B or 10 epochs for 13B models. Intuitively, the exceptional performance of type III (Quality) and type IV (Conditions) may stem from significant visual differences and clear classification boundaries. In contrast, for type I and type II, particularly the latter, the challenges arise due to varying granularity in datasets. The model must not only understand the multimodal input content but also discern the most appropriate classification granularity for the task at hand, complicating the choice of API. For the overall performance, we find that performance without ambiguity surprisingly falls short compared to that with ambiguity. It indirectly highlights that text descriptions cannot substitute for multimodal information, even when the language is exceptionally detailed. This underscores the necessity for LLMs to process the capability to perceive visual- and auditory- instructions, demonstrating the significance of our work.

references: Individual modality          . We further investigate the model‚Äôs perception and understanding of instructions with the specific sole modality and report the results in Table                  8                . Notably, the audio modality stands out, achieving an impressive performance among all models, reaching as high as 93.29% on both the Llama2-Chat-7B and Vicuna-7B model. On the other hand, we notice that pure text-based performance is not particularly satisfactory, falling short in both accuracy and hallucination rate. As for the video modal, it has a greater performance variance than other modals. Interestingly, We find that as the number of epochs increased, the performance of Vicuna-7B drops significantly. A similar situation also occurs on the several other models. We speculate that this may be related to the complexity and scarcity of video data. Since our video task mostly involves video understanding, but with the epochs increasing, the model might start to emphasize the detailed information, which can impact the performance when extending to new unseen data.

references: Multiple options          . We divide the testing set into two to distinguish whether prompts can be linked to multiple API options (one-to-one or one-to-many), and the corresponding performances are shown in Table                  9                . Surprisingly, we discover that one-to-one performance does not surpass, and is significantly behind, the scenario with one-to-many cases, lagging by an average of 21.90% across four 7B models at 5 epochs and 16.14% across four 13B models at 10 epochs . Besides, in terms of the rate of hallucinations, the one-to-one demonstrates a relatively higher incidence. Our analysis suggests that one-to-one pairs may lead to overfitting, where the model becomes overly tuned to specific pairs, hindering its ability to generalize to slightly different queries or contexts. The higher rate of hallucinations also verifies the above speculation.

references: We illustrate our proposed categorization system in Table                   10                  . The system is two-level hierarchical. The coarse level task setting mainly refers to the classification of HuggingFace, while the fine-grained subtask is based on the different task descriptions.
